results.title: The Coconut tree
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description: Examines aspects of life in the Pacific Islands. The coconut is the islands’ only export and the coconut palm is also esential for the people’s immediate livelihood. Shows the products derived from this source by the islanders. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Coconut
results.creator_credit: Dudley Birch, Birch Hill Film Productions and Douglas Hill
results.brief_description: A brief survey of the culture and agriculture of Sri Lanka and study of the cultivation of the coconut as well as the main uses of copra and its by-products.

results.title: The Cocoanuts
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Monta Bell, James R. Cowan, Walter Wanger, Joseph Santley and Robert Florey
results.brief_description: Another hilarious film starring Groucho, Harpo, Zeppo and Chico Marx, ‘Cocoanuts’ is one of the early talkie films and the Marx Brother’s first film. Set in Miami, Groucho Marx plays Hotel Manager, Mr Hammer, struggling to keep his establishment from going under. Hammer’s only paying guest is Mrs Potter (Margaret Dumont), whose daughter Polly (Mary Eaton) is in love with aspiring architect, Bob (Oscar Shaw). Mrs Potter would prefer that Polly marry the respectable Harvey Yates (Cyril Ring); little does she know that he is a jewel thief. Throughout this basic story the four Marx brothers create havoc in their usual slapstick manner, with hilarious results.

results.title: The Coca-Cola Kid
results.creator_credit: Sylvie Le Clezio, David Roe and Dusan Makavejev
results.brief_description: Droll, sometimes wacky comedy in which an American representative from the multi-national soft-drink company of the title heads for Australia to establish his company’s product as the beverage of choice and along the way ends up finding the road to success filled with obstacles that include a passionate romance. Stars Greta Scacchi and Eric Roberts. Cinematography by Dean Semler. Based on the Frank Moorhouse novel. Rated: M

results.title: The Coat
results.brief_description: A story about a girl, her old coat, and why it is okay to be different. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’.

results.title: The Coasts of Clyde
results.creator_credit: Stewart McAllister, British Transport Films and James Ritchie
results.brief_description: A tour of the Firth of Clyde by Bernard Braden, Canadian film and stage actor. Visits to Largs and Dunoon, Rothesay and Loch Lomond; scientists working at a Fishing Research Station, holiday-makers on steamer trips up and down the firth; seals playing around the Kyles of Bute. Finally Braden visits Arran, the island where his grandparents left to sail for the new world.

results.title: The Coastguard
results.creator_credit: Michael Barden, R.H.R. Productions and Simon Campbell-Jones
results.brief_description: The film was made for the 150th anniversary of the founding of H.M. Coastguard. It shows the work carried out by the Coastguard Service in saving life at sea and on the coast, both directly and through their co-ordination with R.A.F. Navy, Post Office and R.N.L.I.

results.title: The Coast: a question of balance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Dept of the Navy and David Hughes
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at Mornington Peninsula, Bellarine Peninsula, Apollo Bay, Torquay, Westernport Bay and Port Melbourne, this film is designed to alert students to the conflict inherent in man’s use of the coastal system, potentially one of the most fragile of environments. Shows the abuse of the sand dune systems through leisure, sport, traffic and the erection of structures, as well as the heavy demands placed by industry and shipping on coastal waters. Stresses that these competing interests will, if left unchecked, ultimately destroy the delicate flora and fauna balance of the coastal system. Music performed by Pink Floyd - “Be careful with that axe, Eugene” Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
